Award.AwardTitle: Reconstructing Cretaceous Mean Climate and Seasonality using the Clumped Isotope Paleothermometer on Mollusks
Award.AbstractNarration:
During the Cretaceous period (66-144 Million Years before present), atmospheric Carbon Dioxide (CO2) levels were elevated and global temperatures were warmer than today, in particular at high latitudes. Current reconstructions disagree on both the magnitude and spatial pattern of the warming during this period. This award supports a Postdoctoral Research Fellow who proposes to develop new temperature estimates for this interval - using the novel proxy method known as carbonate clumped isotope paleothermometry - in order to help resolve the enigma of climate during the Cretaceous, which is a key to understanding the Earth's response to increasing CO2 levels. The Fellow will conduct her research over a two-year period under the mentorship of Professors Kyger C. Lohmann and Christopher J. Poulsen in the Earth & Environmental Sciences Department at the University of Michigan. She also plans to mentor both graduate students and undergraduate research assistants in the Stable Isotope Laboratory and to participate in the department's EARTH CAMP, a program for underrepresented high school students.

The Fellow will attempt to use carbonate clumped isotope paleothermometry to produce the first spatial map of paleo-δ18Osw. This research could provide key insights into both the hydrological cycle and ocean dynamics during the Cretaceous. The direct constraints on Cretaceous δ18Osw produced by this work will improve temperature estimates made using traditional methods, and will demonstrate the power of clumped isotopes to calibrate other proxy methods. In addition to temperature, carbonate clumped isotope paleothermometry has the ability to reconstruct the isotopic composition of seawater (δ18Osw) in the past. Measurements of paleo-δ18Osw over a large spatial scale may reveal differences in global circulation in the past and inform us about past ocean dynamics. The proposed research includes: 1) production of new temperature and seasonality data describing Cretaceous climate, an example of a high-CO2 world; 2) direct measurement of the isotopic composition of seawater (δ18Osw) across a range of latitudes that can test current assumptions about δ18Osw spatial patterns in an ice-free world and provide a basis for future studies requiring past δ18Osw values; 3) comparison of δ18Osw (a quantity highly correlated with salinity) within and between ocean basins, potentially revealing information about global ocean circulation patterns during the Cretaceous.

The PI will also serve as a mentor to minority undergraduates and to minority high school students and involve them directly in the proposed research. Engagement in authentic research that is of importance to society is a proven way to increase persistence in STEM fields for all students, but is particularly important for minority students. This will be an important contribution to efforts to broaden participation in science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The warm, greenhouse climate that existed during the Cretaceous period (66-144 Ma) can serve as an interesting analog for our potential future climate, due to its elevated atmospheric CO2 levels, warmer temperatures, and higher sea level. Temperature estimates from geochemical and botanical proxies indicate temperatures were warmer than today during the Cretaceous, but the magnitude and spatial pattern of the warming is still under debate. In particular, some proxies suggest a very shallow equator-to-pole temperature gradient (temperature difference between low and high latitudes) that has been difficult to explain or reproduce in global climate model simulations. This grant funded an effort to reexamine the question of the equator-to-pole temperature gradient in the Late Cretaceous using a new paleo-temperature proxy called the carbonate clumped isotope paleothermometer. This proxy relates the isotopic ordering within a carbonate lattice (in this case calcium carbonate in bivalve and gastropod shells) to formation temperature (in this case surface ocean temperature).  

We produced new temperature estimates from sites around the globe, for a total of ~200 individual samples analyzed, and compared this data to new, cutting-edge global climate model simulations. We found that the models and data agree fairly well, with neither indicating the extremely shallow equator-to-pole gradient suggested by some earlier data. Along the way towards creating this global data set, we also performed a few focused studies in the following regions: the high latitude site of Seymour Island, Antarctica and the Western Interior Seaway.

The Seymour Island study [Petersen et al., 2016, Nature Communications, 7:12079] documented changes in high latitude climate over the ~3 million years leading up to the Cretaceous-Paleogene (KPg) boundary, when one of the “Big Five” mass extinctions occurred. The debate continues over whether a meteorite impact or long-lasting volcanism caused this mass extinction. We found a rapid, significant warming event occurring prior to the KPg boundary, aligning with the onset of Deccan Traps volcanism in India and with a first pulse of extinction at our site (see Figure 1). A second pulse of extinction occurs at the KPg boundary itself, in time with the Chicxulub meteorite impact event. This result directly links end-Cretaceous extinction at Seymour Island to both the volcanic and meteorite kill mechanisms.

The Western Interior Seaway was a shallow ocean that covered much of the central U.S. during the Late Cretaceous. We measured the temperature and isotopic composition of waters in this seaway using bivalves and gastropods from many different environments (open water, estuarine, freshwater) [Petersen et al., 2016, Geology, v.44, 903-906]. We found that the seaway was less salty than open ocean waters in the Gulf of Mexico, likely due to the influence of continental runoff.
